description: From Middle English cripel, crepel, crüpel, from Old English crypel (“crippled; a cripple”), from Proto-Germanic *krupilaz (“tending to crawl; a cripple”), from Proto-Indo-European *grewb- (“to bend, crouch, crawl”), from Proto-Indo-European *ger- (“to bend, twist”), equivalent to creep +‎ -le. Cognate with Dutch kreupel, Low German Kröpel, German Krüppel, Old Norse kryppill.

entries.meaning: (sometimes offensive) a person who has severely impaired physical abilities because of deformation, injury, or amputation of parts of the body.
examples: He returned from war a cripple.

entries.meaning: A shortened wooden stud or brace used to construct the portion of a wall above a door or above and below a window.
(among lumbermen) A rocky shallow in a stream.

verbs.description: cripple (third-person singular simple present cripples, present participle crippling, simple past and past participle crippled)

entries.meaning: To make someone a cripple; to cause someone to become physically impaired.
examples: The car bomb crippled five passers-by.
My ambitions were crippled by a lack of money.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) To cause severe and disabling damage; to make unable to function normally.
examples: With all these people all around / I'm crippled with anxiety / But I'm told it's where I'm s'posed to be.

entries.meaning: To release a product (especially a computer program) with reduced functionality, in some cases, making the item essentially worthless.
examples: The word processor was released in a crippled demonstration version that did not allow you to save.

entries.meaning: (slang, video games) To nerf something which is overpowered.
